isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - SUPPLEMENTAL DIAGNOSTIC ANALYSIS - DIAGNOSING SCUFFED INJECTORS

svcproc.title: Key-On Engine-Running Injector Test
svcproc.para: The injector Scuff test is designed to detect problems with injection and combustion events. Performing a cylinder contribution test will analyze the individual contribution of each of the power cylinders. Its primary function is to detect a bad injector, although it will also detect problems that could affect the overall performance of the power cylinders (i.e.: valves, push rods, pistons, rings, etc.). Further diagnostic testing may be necessary to resolve mechanical issues.
During this test the ECM will control fuel delivery and determine each cylinder's power contribution. If a cylinder is not performing satisfactorily, a Diagnostic Trouble Code may be set.
Some of the key areas to examine on the graphical display of the cylinder contribution test are:

step1.para: When the test begins, the engine speed increases in increments up to 850 rpm.
The ECM increases fuel delivery to cylinder No.1 (over-fuels) which causes engine speed to increase.
Fuel is reduced to remaining cylinders to maintain 850 rpm
The ECM decreases fuel delivery to cylinder No.1 (under-fuels) which causes engine speed to decrease.
Fuel is increased to the remaining cylinders to maintain 850 rpm
At this point 2 key observations are noted:

item.para: The ECM compares fuel delivery of the remaining 5 cylinders during over-fuel condition
The ECM compares fuel delivery of remaining 5 cylinders during under-fuel condition

step1.para: If the difference is not what the ECM expects, a DTC may be set for an under-contributing cylinder. The procedure will repeat for the remaining cylinders (in numerical order) until the test is complete.
The engine speed returns to low idle and the test is complete.

note.para: During the cylinder contribution test, the fuel rate graph represents fuel delivery to the remaining 5 cylinders.

svcproc.para: The cylinder contribution test begins with cylinder No.1 (front cylinder) and is performed sequentially. The rpm fluctuation on engines with more than one severely scuffed injector can be enough to stop the cylinder contribution test.
